unnormalised: ## Decoding the Numbers in Your Medical Records: A Patient's Guide
normalised: ## Decoding the Numbers in Your Medical Records: A Patient's Guide

unnormalised: Hey everyone! Ever stared at your medical bill or a discharge summary and felt like you were deciphering a foreign language? You're not alone! Those numbers, codes, and percentages can be super confusing. But understanding them is actually empowering. It helps you take charge of your health and communicate better with your doctors. So, let's break it down, shall we?
normalised: Hey everyone! Ever stared at your medical bill or a discharge summary and felt like you were deciphering a foreign language? You're alone! Those numbers, codes, and percentages can be super confusing. But understanding them is actually empowering. It helps you take charge of your health and communicate better with your doctors. So, let's break it down, shall we?

unnormalised: First off, think about your blood pressure. You'll often see something like 120/80 mmHg. The top number (systolic) represents the pressure when your heart beats, and the bottom number (diastolic) is the pressure when your heart rests between beats. Aim for those lower numbers, folks! High BP can be a silent killer. Speaking of, my last reading was a tad high at 135/85 mmHg! Gotta cut down on the samosas, I guess.
normalised: First off, think about your blood pressure. You'll often see something like one hundred and twenty over eighty m-m H-g. The top number (systolic) represents the pressure when your heart beats, and the bottom number (diastolic) is the pressure when your heart rests between beats. Aim for those lower numbers, folks! High B-P can be a silent killer. Speaking of, my last reading was a tad high at one hundred and thirty five over eighty five m-m H-g! Gotta cut down on the samosas, I guess.

unnormalised: Then there's the world of lab results. You might see things like "Cholesterol: 220 mg/dL" or "HbA1c: 7.2%." Cholesterol levels should ideally be under 200 mg/dL. That HbA1c, which reflects average blood sugar over the past 2-3 months, should be below 6.5% if you don't have diabetes. For diabetics, the target will be given by your doctor. Remember, these are just general guidelines. Your doctor will interpret them based on your individual health profile.

unnormalised: Hospital stays are a whirlwind, and those discharge summaries are packed with numbers. Pay attention to things like your heart rate (beats per minute or BPM) and oxygen saturation (SpO2 percentage). A normal resting heart rate is generally between 60-100 BPM. And your SpO2 should ideally be above 95%.

And your S-p-O two should ideally be above ninety five percent.

unnormalised: Dates are another crucial element. Your medical history relies heavily on tracking dates ‚Äì when symptoms started, when tests were performed, when medications were prescribed. You might see dates written as 15/07/2024 or 07/15/2024, depending on the format. Keep a record of your appointments, vaccination dates (like your COVID-19 booster on 23/11/2024), and when you started taking any new medications.

unnormalised: And finally, dosages! Pay VERY close attention to the dosage of any medications you're taking. You might see something like "Amoxicillin 500mg three times a day" or "Vitamin D 1000 IU daily." Don't mix them up and don't self-medicate! Always double-check with your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure about anything.
